text:
i just created a test page as a "child" (as opposed to "sibling-after") in order
to start a subtree.

this entry ends up in the metadata file:

<element key="relation">
<value>child</value>
</element>

it's perfectly nonsensical since it does not store the parent.
and if it did, it would duplicate data that belongs in the sitemap.
either way, it should just go. i'll put an entry in bugzilla.

if we want something like dc:relation, that's fine, but having it default to
incomplete and sitemap-specific data is wrong. 
a better use would be dcterms:replaces/uuid to denote new document revisions.
creator: nettings@apache.org

text:
I guess this is because the usecase checks for all DC elements
if equally named request parameters exist, to allow to initialize
the meta data. The name "relation" is just an accidential match.

Maybe we should use prefixes for the meta data request parameters?
creator: andreas@apache.org

text: Dublin core parameter names are now prefixed with "dublincore." .
creator: andreas@apache.org
